SENT.plain: Thrombus is a frequent cause of shunt malfunction both of the proximal end following intraventricular hemorrhage and of the distal catheter of a vascular shunt
Continued blockages may result in numerous shunt revisions until the blood has been cleared
We have treated 3 children with shunt malfunctions secondary to thrombus with urokinase, a thrombolytic agent

Two children had intraventricular hemorrhage following a shunt revision and were treated with intrashunt urokinase, and 1 with occlusion of an atrial catheter was treated with both intrashunt and systemic urokinase
All were symptomatic at the time of treatment (headaches, vomiting, full fontanel, somnolence) and all had ventriculomegaly demonstrated on computed tomography
Various dosage regimens were used with total intrashunt doses of 20,000, 50,000, and 70,000 IU
All improved clinically, computed tomography scans demonstrated improvement, and all were discharged from the hospital
There were no complications of the urokinase administration
The 2 children with proximal occlusion have not required further shunt revisions at 12 and 27 months following treatment
The infant with atrial end occlusion subsequently underwent two proximal revisions with eventual removal of the atrial catheter because of infection
We conclude the intrashunt urokinase can be of value in the treatment of shunts by blood and blood products
